question_paper.question_paper_name: IIT M FOUNDATION QUIZ2 EXAM QPB1 10 July 2022 IBA
question_paper.question_paper_description: 2022 July: IIT M FOUNDATION QUIZ2 EXAM

questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions:        I was nine years old, sitting stiffly at the dining table in my blue-and-white school uniform, and across from me sat my mother, who had come home from work at the university registry, elegant in her swishy skirt, smelling of Poison perfume and saying she wanted to watch me eat. I still do not know who told her that I was skipping lunch before school. Perhaps it was the houseboy, Fide. Perhaps it was my little brother Kenechukwu, who went to school in the morning and came home just before I left. The firm set of her mouth told me that I had no choice but to eat the garri and soup placed on the table. I made the sign of the cross. I plucked a morsel from the soft lump of garri. I lightly moulded it with my fingers. I dipped it into the soup. I swallowed. My throat itched. I disliked all the variants of this quintessential Nigerian food, whether made from corn, cassava, or yams, whether cooked or stirred or pounded in a mortar until they became a soft mash. It was jokingly called “swallow,” because one swallowed the morsels without chewing; it was easy to tell that a person chewing garri was a foreigner.        “Hurry up,” my mother said. “You will be late for school.” We had garri for lunch every day except Sunday, when we had rice and stew and sometimes a lush salad that contained everything from baked beans to boiled eggs and was served with dollops of creamy dressing. The soups gave some variety to lunch: the yellowish egusi, made of ground melon seeds and vegetables; onugbu, rich with dark-green bitterleaf; okro, with its sticky sauce; nsala, with beef chunks floating in a thin herb-filled broth. I disliked them all.        That afternoon, it was egusi soup. My mother’s eyes were steady behind her glasses. “Are you playing with that food or eating it?” she asked. I said I was eating. Finally, I finished and said, “Mummy, thank you,” as all well-brought-up Igbo children were supposed to after a meal. I had just stepped outside the carpeted dining area and onto the polished concrete floor of the passage when my stomach churned and recoiled and the garri and soup rushed up my throat.  —Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Real Food

questions.question_text_1: What is the meaning of the word “quintessential”?
question_texts: What is the meaning of the word “quintessential”?

options.option_text: Representing the most typical example of something
Something that is needed on an immediate basis

The firm set of her mouth told me that I had no choice but to eat the garri and soup placed on the table. I made the sign of the cross. I plucked a morsel from the soft lump of garri. I lightly moulded it with my fingers. I dipped it into the soup. I swallowed. My throat itched. I disliked all the variants of this quintessential Nigerian food, whether made from corn, cassava, or yams, whether cooked or stirred or pounded in a mortar until they became a soft mash. It was jokingly called “swallow,” because one swallowed the morsels without chewing; it was easy to tell that a person chewing garri was a foreigner.        “Hurry up,” my mother said. “You will be late for school.” We had garri for lunch every day except Sunday, when we had rice and stew and sometimes a lush salad that contained everything from baked beans to boiled eggs and was served with dollops of creamy dressing. The soups gave some variety to lunch: the yellowish egusi, made of ground melon seeds and vegetables; onugbu, rich with dark-green bitterleaf; okro, with its sticky sauce; nsala, with beef chunks floating in a thin herb-filled broth. I disliked them all.        That afternoon, it was egusi soup. My mother’s eyes were steady behind her glasses. “Are you playing with that food or eating it?” she asked. I said I was eating. Finally, I finished and said, “Mummy, thank you,” as all well-brought-up Igbo children were supposed to after a meal. I had just stepped outside the carpeted dining area and onto the polished concrete floor of the passage when my stomach churned and recoiled and the garri and soup rushed up my throat.  —Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Real Food

questions.question_text_1: From the passage, what can you infer about what happened next to the narrator/protagonist?
question_texts: From the passage, what can you infer about what happened next to the narrator/protagonist?

options.option_text: She broke down into tears because she didn’t want to have garri.
She threw up the food she had taken.
She silently cursed her fate and went to school.
She came back to confront her mother in an argument.

questions.question_text_1: A Sunday lunch at the author’s house would consist of:
question_texts: A Sunday lunch at the author’s house would consist of:

options.option_text: No, the given sentence is wrong. The correct sentence is: Leela, along with herbrothers, ride a cycle.

questions.question_text_1: ‘I manage to travel for pleasure once in a blue moon.’ What does “once in a blue moon” mean?
question_texts: ‘I manage to travel for pleasure once in a blue moon.’ What does “once in a blue moon” mean?

options.option_text: Once a month, when there is full moon
Twice a month, when there is no moon and when there is a full moon

Putting all her eggs in one basket
